column6: Daniel|Planetary and Space Science|126||1|Apollo lunar regolith samples are not available in quantity for engineering studies with In-Situ Resource Utilization (ISRU). Therefore
column7: with expectation of a return to the Moon
column8: dozens of regolith (soil) simulants have been developed
column9: to some extent a result of inefficient distribution of NASA-sanctioned simulants. In this paper
column10: we review many of these simulants
column11: with evaluations of their short-comings. In 2010
column12: the NAC-PSS committee instructed the Lunar Exploration Advisory Group (LEAG) and CAPTEM (the NASA committee recommending on the appropriations of Apollo samples) to report on the status of lunar regolith simulants. This report is reviewed here-in
column13: along with a list of the plethora of lunar regolith simulants and references. In addition
column17: which has many of the properties sought for ISRU studies
column18: should be available in reasonable amounts for ISRU studies.

column1: 1994E&PSL.126....1M|1994|Primitive <SUP>87</SUP>Sr/<SUP>86</SUP>Sr from an Archean barite and conjecture on the Earth's age and origin|McCulloch
column2: Malcolm T.|Earth and Planetary Science Letters|126|1-3|1|A primitive measured<SUP>87</SUP>Sr/<SUP>86</SUP>Sr ratio of 0.700510 ± 9 is reported for an early Archean (3450 Ma) barite from the Pilbara Block of Western Australia. The low <SUP>87</SUP>Rb/<SUP>86</SUP>Sr ratio in the barite (0.00015) enables a precise initial <SUP>87</SUP>Sr/<SUP>86</SUP>Sr ratio of 0.700502 ± 10 to be calculated at 3450 Ma. This initial ratio is the same as that previously inferred for mineral separates from Onverwacht Group basalts of similar age and
column4: implies a relatively high <SUP>87</SUP>Sr/<SUP>86</SUP>Sr ratio of 0.70050 ± 2 for the early Archean mantle. Assuming that the upper mantle has become progressively depleted in Rb/Sr due to the growth of continental crust
column5: then this allows an estimate to be placed on the Earth's initial Sr ratio of 0.69940 ± 10 (relative to NBS 987 = 0.71021). This ratio
column7: is significantly higher than that measured for the Moon (LUNI = 0.69900 ± 2) or the well-characterised achondrite Angra dos Reis (ADOR = 0.69893 ± 2). Assuming a <SUP>87</SUP>Rb/<SUP>86</SUP>Sr ratio of ̃ 0.4 ( ̃ 50% of chondrites) for the terrestrial precursors gives an accretion interval for the Earth of ̃ 60-100 Ma after ADOR and ̃ 40-80 Ma after the formation of the Moon. This chronology is compatible with either an early ( ̃ 4540 Ma) impact origin for the Moon or
column10: with the Moon being derived predominantly from a low <SUP>87</SUP>Sr/<SUP>86</SUP>Sr (0.6990) impactor. In both scenarios the final accretion of the Earth was completed relatively late at ̃ 4480 Ma. An ̃ 60-100 Ma timescale for the accretion of the Earth is consistent with Pb isotopic constraints for core formation and also allows an extended interval for cooling of the terrestrial magma ocean
column11: and hence avoids the dilemma of a highly differentiated early Earth.
